botanical_details.genus: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Patio roses are small bushy shrubs with clusters of single to double, slightly fragrant flowers about 3cm across, over a long period in summer and autumn

how_to_grow.cultivation: Thrives on full sun in moist but free-draining or free-draining soil. Avoid planting in sites that have previously been used for growing roses
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by budding or hardwood cuttings
how_to_grow.pruning: Require little annual pruning, apart from removing dead, damaged, diseased or congested branches completely in late winter. If it becomes too big for their allotted space, cut back vigorous stems by a third and prune side shoots to within two or three buds. To totally renovate, cut all stems to within 10cm from the base.
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to aphid , caterpillars, deer, glasshouse red spider mite, leafhopper , rabbits, rose leaf-rolling sawfly, scale insects
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to downy mildew, powdery mildew, rose black spot and rose rust
